results.title: The India trip
results.creator_credit: Bill Davies, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Pondicherry, an ancient city near the Southern tip of India, was for several centuries an outpost of France. Now the French influence has faded but another, stranger, colony is growing on its outskirts - Auroville, a community of Europeans and North Americans who have come to live the contemplative life. They are devotees of Sri Aurobindo, a Bengali poet and mystic, and their guru is a ninety-four-year-old woman from France. This spiritual mecca is described in the film by Albert Jordan, a professor from Concordia University, Montreal, who, in 1971, with his family, spent a year there.

results.title: India: the struggle for food
results.brief_description: Following the life of a farmer in the upper Ganges Valley, we see the problems which beset India’s food production. the use of primitive methods of farming, the growing rural population and the resulting migration of farmers to the cities, all contribute to low crop yields. Under government auspices, the Community Development Program is trying to improve farming methods and enrich village life.

results.title: India fights kans
results.creator_credit: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
results.brief_description: Shows how kans grass, a deep-rooted weed, has been spreading through the central plains of India, choking food crops. Shows how the Indian Government received aid from the World Bank, and the arrival in 1949 of 300 tractors purchased with the loan. These are shown as they plough deep to uproot the weed, and as they are turned to other uses such as clearing scrub and rain forests. Includes glimpses of Indian peasants celebrating at their harvest festival.

results.title: India and Pakistan: the lands and people
results.brief_description: The great subcontinent of India, comprising both Pakistan and the Union of India, is examined in terms of its four major geographic regions. The range in climate and land forms of these regions is seen to affect both crop production and population density. Life in cities, as well as in rural areas, is surveyed as an aid to understanding these key countries of Asia.

results.title: Index to progress
results.creator_credit: Walter F. Broome and Beechdale Educational Films
results.brief_description: A survey of urban and rural library services in Great Britain. Shows the following various types of libraries and the services provided by each: Reference, Commercial, Technical and Children’s libraries and the local collection.

results.title: Independent Nigeria
results.creator_credit: George Sturt, Beric Knight-Simpson, Federal Film Unit and Nigeria. Federal Information Unit
results.brief_description: Nigeria on the eve of independence. Gives a general picture of the country, showing its progress in economic, political and social spheres. Recent developments in agriculture and industry; medical education and social services; housing and transport, are illustrated. Describes the different races, religions and customs of the people of Nigeria, and includes colourful scenes of traditional pageantry.

results.title: Independence Day USA
results.creator_credit: John G. Fuller and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Describes the various ways in which individual Americans celebrate their Independence Day, July 4th. They honour the heroes responsible for the Declaration of Independence and the national ideals of human rights embodied in it.

results.title: Incredible Floridas
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Incredible Floridas is composer Richard Meale’s homage to the French poet, Arthur Rimbaud. Scored for woodwind, percussion and string instruments, it was written for the “Fires of London” and their conductor, Peter Maxwell Davies, and premiered in London in 1971 to a enthusiastic reception. Richard Meale is a leader in contemporary music in Australia. Also available on DVD [319174].

results.title: [The Incredible bread machine]
results.creator_credit: Theo Kamecke, John W. Doswell and World Research
results.brief_description: Based on a book of the same title by R. W. Grant, first published in 1966, and updated and extensively revised by Susan Love Brown and the student staff of Campus Studies Institute, World Research, under the supervision of Patty Newman in 1974. This docudrama film contains re-enactments based on true facts of various events that took place during the 1960’s and 1970’s relating to government department abuse of individual freedom and choice. For example, an Amish farmer who could not pay his taxes and subsequently lost his farm (which eventually turned into a parking lot), and a police agent drug bust on the wrong house (with no compensation to the couple who lived there). It focuses on government regulation and intervention, lobbyists and monopolies versus people’s freedom of choice and the right to food, shelter and equality.
